Title: Israel/Palestine in World Politics.
Ever since the emergence of the Zionist movement in the late 19th century, the political future of the land known as both Israel and Palestine has been the subject of fierce international debate. This seminar will examine how, exactly, this land has been discussed in international forums and in various countries, as well as how leaders of both Israelis and Palestinians have worked to chart a foreign policy for their respective peoples. Students will be given an overview of Israeli foreign policy and Palestinian attempts at global outreach since 1948 before the course moves on to explore the politics of the Israeli-Palestinian conflict in various regions of the world.
Course requirements include regular preparation and participation, facilitating one classroom discussion, one short review essay, and a final original research paper. While there is no fixed prerequisite for the course, students should either have some background in the politics and history of Israel or the Middle East, or have previous studied another country or region that they plan to examine in their research.
Note: this is not an introductory course. Students without any background on the topic may wish to instead enroll in the "Israeli-Palestinian Conflict" taught in Spring 2024 or other 200-level courses on Israel/Palestine.
